column5: 5aa86a38-38dd-4898-af67-07cdd851a27d;The Copernicus boundary layers cover the EEA38 member states and United Kingdom including the French DOM (French Guiana GF
column8: Mayotte YT and Reunion RE).#The Copernicus Boundary Layer  provides both land masks for the countries as well as national boundaries. The datasets are based on a rasterisation of the Boundary Layer vector product. The raster products are available with 250 m buffer in these resolutions: raster 10m
column9: raster 20m and raster 100m.##The production of the Border Products was coordinated by the European Environment Agency in the frame of the EU Copernicus programme. The use of the raster 10m
column10: raster 20m and the vector data has to be agreed with EEA.

column2: 205e2db2-4e35-4b1b-bf84-271c4a82248c;The Copernicus Coastal Zones (CZ) monitors landscape dynamics in European coastal territory to an inland depth of 10 km with a total area of approximately 730
column6: nature reserves). The production of the coastal zone layers was coordinated by the European Environment Agency (EEA) in the frame of the EU Copernicus programme
column7: as part of the Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS) Local Component.##The CZ dataset is distributed in vector format
column8: in a single OGC GeoPackage SQLite file covering the area of interest for the years 2012 and 2018.

column1: Copernicus Coastal Zones Changes;c88e743d-e838-49e1-8c80-54f26bcf4ab8;The Coastal Zones LC/LU Change (CZC) 2012-2018 is providing the Land Cover / Land Use (LC/ LU) change for areas along the coastline of the EEA38 countries and the United Kingdom
column2: between the reference years 2012 and 2018. The Copernicus Coastal Zones (CZ) monitors landscape dynamics in European coastal territory to an inland depth of 10 km with a total area of approximately 730
column6: nature reserves). The production of the coastal zone layers was coordinated by the European Environment Agency (EEA) in the frame of the EU Copernicus programme
column7: as part of the Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS) Local Component.##The CZ dataset is distributed in vector format
column8: in a single OGC GeoPackage SQLite file covering the area of interest for the years 2012 and 2018.

column10: 71c95a07-e296-44fc-b22b-415f42acfdf0;The Copernicus Corine Land Cover (CLC) datasets produced within the frame of the Copernicus Land Monitoring Service referring to land cover / land use for the years 1990
column13: 2012 and 2018. For each year raster and vector data is accessible.##CLC service has a long-time heritage (formerly known as CORINE Land Cover Programme)
column14: coordinated by the European Environment Agency (EEA). It provides consistent and thematically detailed information on land cover and land cover changes across Europe.#CLC datasets are based on the classification of satellite images produced by the national teams of the participating countries - the EEA members and cooperating countries (EEA39). National CLC inventories are then further integrated into a seamless land cover map of Europe.##The resulting European database relies on standard methodology and nomenclature with following base parameters: 44 classes in the hierarchical 3-level CLC nomenclature; minimum mapping unit (MMU) for status layers is 25 hectares; minimum width of linear elements is 100 metres.

column8: f30f1000-7cf8-43bb-872c-5eb093911b24;The Copernicus Corine Land Cover Change (CHA) datasets produced within the frame of the Copernicus Land Monitoring Service referring to land cover / land use status between the years 1990-2000
column10: 2006-2012 and 2012-2018. For each year raster and vector data is accessible.##CLC service has a long-time heritage (formerly known as CORINE Land Cover Programme)
column11: coordinated by the European Environment Agency (EEA). It provides consistent and thematically detailed information on land cover and land cover changes across Europe.#CLC datasets are based on the classification of satellite images produced by the national teams of the participating countries - the EEA members and cooperating countries (EEA39). National CLC inventories are then further integrated into a seamless land cover map of Europe.##The resulting European database relies on standard methodology and nomenclature with following base parameters: 44 classes in the hierarchical 3-level CLC nomenclature; minimum mapping unit (MMU) for status layers is 25 hectares; minimum width of linear elements is 100 metres.

column2: f0f9610c-8446-45ed-88bd-eaa137bef5ab;The Copernicus Delineation of Riparian Zones datasets represent transitional areas occurring between land and freshwater ecosystems
column4: soil and biotic conditions and strongly influenced by the stream water. They provide a wide range of riparian functions (e.g. chemical filtration
column7: aquatic life and riparian wildlife support
column8: etc.) and ecosystem services.##The Riparian Zones products support the objectives of several European legal acts and policy initiatives
column9: such as the EU Biodiversity Strategy to 2020
column10: the Habitats and Birds Directives and the Water Framework Directive.##The Ripariean Zones dataset is accessible in raster format with a 50m-resolution and a in vector format with a 10m-resolution published in 2015.##The production of the Riparian Zones products was coordinated by the European Environment Agency in the frame of the EU Copernicus programme.

column4: 11e54513-eaee-407b-8f0a-4f321cbf9974;The Copernicus Dominant Leaf Type (DLT) datasets covers three years 2012
column5: 2015 and 2018. The DLT raster product provides a basic land cover classification with 3 thematic classes at 10m/20m spatial resolution:#* non-tree covered areas#* broadleaved areas#* coniferous areas##The Copernicus Dominant Leaf Change 2015-2018 dataset covers the change between the reference years 2015 and 2018 and consists of 7 thematic classes at 20m spatial resolution:#* unchanged areas with no tree cover#* new broadleaved cover#* new coniferous cover#* loss of broadleaved cover#* loss of coniferous cover#* unchanged areas with tree cover#* potential change among dominant leaf types##The datasets covers the full of EEA38 member countries and the United Kingdom. The production of the High Resolution Forest layers was coordinated by the European Environment Agency (EEA) in the frame of the EU Copernicus programme.

column4: bda52886-fc81-44e0-8616-2fcdf957af80;The Copernicus Border Expert product covers EEA38 member countries and the United Kingdom (former EEA39) in vector format (GDB
column11: Mayotte YT and Reunion RE) as well as the Falkland Islands (FK). For the provision of land monitoring services within the Copernicus programme
column14: sufficiently detailed boundary layer is required at EEA
column15: which provides a “land mask” for the area that needs to be monitored.##The boundary layer is further derived from the EU-Hydro Coastline Version 3 from EEA
column16: the EEA coastline for analysis Version 2
column17: the EBM GISCO Hybrid Layer from EEA
column18: the “Water and Wetness High Resolution Layer 2015” from EEA and the JRC-Global Surface Water Occurrence layer. The production of this EEA39 Border Expert Product was coordinated by the European Environment Agency in the frame of the EU Copernicus programme.##MPORTANT NOTE: These dataset are only available for internal use within EEA in the context of the EU Copernicus programme. Copyright restrictions apply
column19: as in this product ungeneralised data from EuroGeographics EuroBoundary Map Version 12 is included. Use of this dataset has therefore to be agreed with EEA and ultimately with EuroGeographics.

column2: 3473589f-0854-4601-919e-2e7dd172ff50;The Copernicus EU-DEM products covers EEA38 member countries and the United Kingdom.##The Copernicus EU-DEM  v1.0 is a digital surface model (DSM) representing the first surface as illuminated by the sensors. It is a hybrid product based on SRTM and ASTER GDEM data fused by a weighted averaging approach and generated as a contiguous dataset divided into 1 degree by 1 degree tiles
column3: corresponding to the SRTM naming convention.##The Copernicus EU-DEM v1.1 is a resulting dataset of the EU-DEM v1.0 upgrade which enhances the correction of geo-positioning issues
column5: improving the vertical accuracy of EU-DEM using ICESat as reference and ensuring consistency with EU-Hydro public beta.##EU-DEM v1.1 is available in Geotiff 32 bits format. It is a contiguous dataset divided into 100x100 km tiles
column6: resulting in a total of 1992 tiles of 4000x4000 pixel at 25m resolution with vertical accuracy: +/- 7 meters RMSE.##The implementation of EU-DEM v1.0 was coordinated by the European Commission in 2009-2011 in the framework of the Reference Data Access (RDA) Action of the EU GMES/Copernicus programme.##EU-DEM v1.1 upgrade was coordinated by the European Environment Agency (EEA) in the frame of the EU Copernicus programme.

column2: 393359a7-7ebd-4a52-80ac-1a18d5f3db9c;The Copernicus EU-Hydro products covers EEA38 member countries and the United Kingdom providing photo-interpreted river network
column3: consistent of surface interpretation of water bodies (lakes and wide rivers)
column4: and a drainage model (also called Drainage Network)
column6: with catchments and drainage lines and nodes.##The coastline is also included for each basin in the EU-Hydro River Network Database.##The EU-Hydro dataset is distributed in separate files (river network and drainage network) for each of the 35 major basins of the EEA38 member countries and UK area
column7: in GDB and GPKG formats.##The production of EU-Hydro and the derived layers was coordinated by the European Environment Agency in the frame of the EU Copernicus programme.

f97a2763-748c-4687-a141-685e954eb2dd;The Copernicus European High Resolution (HR) image mosaics provides coverage over the EEA38 member countries and the United Kingdom in the following resolutions: 5-
column8: 10- and 20 meter.# #High Resolution 20 meter (false colour):#The surface covered by the image dataset is 5.8 million square kilometres and has a spatial resolution of 20 meters. The imagery is composed during specific acquisition windows between 2005 and 2013. Images are derived from the following satellite sensors:#* Resourcesat-1/-2#* SPOT-4/-5##High Resolution 5 meter (true colour):#The High Resolution Image Mosaic 2012 image dataset covers 5.8 million square kilometres and has a spatial resolution of 5 meters. The imagery is composed during specific acquisition windows in 2011
column9: 2012 and 2013. Images are derived from the following satellite sensors:#* RapidEye constellation##The input imagery for the creation of the mosaic is provided by ESA. Due to license restrictions
column11: 2009 and 2012 is only available as a web service (WMS)
column12: and not for data download.##0 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 0##High Resolution 10 meter (true and false colour):#The High Resolution Image Mosaic 2018 provides cloud-free HR false colour imagery. The mosaics has been produced in 10 meter resolution
column13: and consists of 1079 tiles. Images are derived from the following satellite sensors:#* Sentinel-2##Since the pan-European High Resolution Mosaic 2018 is created exclusively from Sentinel-2 data
column14: the imagery can be downloaded from The Copernicus Open Access Hub (mission ongoing since 2015) at https://scihub.copernicus.eu/. Global Sentinel-2 Image Mosaics Hub at https://land.copernicus.eu/imagery-in-situ/global-image-mosaics/ can be also used to automatically create mosaics over the area of interest.##Natural-color (also called true-color) images use red
column16: and blue. #False-color images use at least one wavelength outside the visible range
column17: or some other type of data.
